I.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE SUBPROJECT 
A.  Overall Progress of the TA cluster 
1.  The knowledge  and  support  technical  assistance  (TA) cluster  was  approved  on  15 
September 2018. The overall TA cluster is estimated at $1.5 million. The TA subproject 1 was 
approved on 15 October 2018, while the TA subprojects 3 and 4 are being processed for approval 
within 2018. 
 
B.  Subproject Outcome 
2.   The subproject will have the following outcome: capacity and institutional framework for 
integrating poverty reduction into eco-compensation policies and programs enhanced. This will 
support the outputs of the overall TA cluster and the subproject will be aligned with the following 
impact: green economic development and ecological protection in the Yangtze River Economic 
Belt achieved.1 The National Development and Reform Commission is committed to undertaking 
policy research on the impact of ecological conservation and eco-compensation programs to 
poverty reduction and rural welfare objectives. To undertake this policy research, the Western 
Region Development Department (WRDD) requested the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) 
support for the outputs outlined below.  
 
C.  Subproject Outputs, Methods, and Activities   
3.  Output  1:  Analysis  of  the  current  experience  of  eco-compensation  and  other 
conservation programs in targeting rural welfare improvement and poverty alleviation 
prepared. This output will prepare (i) a summary of the experience and performance of a 
representative selection of eco-compensation and other conservation program case studies; and 
(ii) a ranking and assessment of the importance of various program design and implementation 
elements on the effectiveness of conservation programs in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) 
to jointly achieve rural welfare improvement and ecological outcomes. Preliminary case studies 
to capture locations with both high conservation value and poverty alleviation potential include 
selected municipalities in the provinces of Sichuan, Hubei, and Jiangxi, all of which are within 
both national key ecological function zones and nationally-designated poverty areas. Case 
studies will provide detailed descriptions of the program structure, development process, timeline 
and implementation, as well as the socioeconomic, ecological and institutional context of the 
regions and communities targeted.  
 
4.  Output 2: Policy brief integrating poverty reduction and rural welfare improvement 
goals with eco-compensation developed. Indicative activities under this output include (i) 
development of a poverty and high conservation value area “mapping” for the PRC to identify 
regions of high overlap that would be well-suited to joint targeting of poverty alleviation and 
conservation; (ii) a review of the literature summarizing international best practice in program 
development, design and implementation for effectively achieving both conservation outcomes 
and rural welfare improvement; (iii) an international conference on how poverty alleviation and 
rural welfare improvement can best be linked with conservation targets, with international experts 
sharing their experience and recommendations, and the findings of Output 1 and the poverty-
environment  mapping  preliminary  results  presented,  discussed  and  given  feedback  from 
conference participants; and (iv) preparation of final policy recommendations, based on the

poverty mapping, summary of international best practice, international conference findings, and 
Output 1 analysis, on the next steps for integrating poverty alleviation with eco-compensation.  
 
5.  Output  3:  Subproject  findings  disseminated  and  shared  with  policymakers. 
Indicative activities under this output include (i) various national workshops targeting government 
officials administering key ecological function zones, to share a summary of the findings of 
Outputs 1 and 2, and to obtain feedback on these and current challenges faced by these officials 
in managing these zones; (ii) presentation of these findings in selected international workshops 
and conferences, especially those hosted by other ADB member countries; (iii) development of 
2–5 brief news items, articles or blogs on the subproject findings, and publishing of these in 
various international platforms such as Development Asia; (iv) a study tour in ADB member 
countries for five key national and provincial government officials to discuss these findings and 
consult with select international organizations that have expertise in this field, with the goal of 
strengthening the knowledge and capacity of these government officials to integrate poverty 
reduction with eco-compensation and other conservation programs; and (v) strengthening the 
capacity of the existing regional knowledge hub to effectively function as a community of practice 
for mainstreaming poverty reduction into eco-compensation. 
 
D.  Subproject Cost and Financing 
6.  The TA subproject is estimated to cost $380,000, of which $350,000 will be financed on a 
grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF-other  sources).  The  key 
expenditure items are listed in Appendix 2. The government will provide counterpart support in 
the form of counterpart staff, office accommodation, administrative assistance, and other in-kind 
contributions. 
 
E.  Subproject Implementation Arrangements 
7.  WRDD will be the executing and implementing agency and provide oversight, ensure 
coordination across sectors, and provide guidance to the implementation. A comprehensive 
project management office will be established in WRDD. The project management office will be 
the main contact point for ADB and will provide oversight and liaison with the districts and counties. 
The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 1.

8.  Consulting  services.  It  is  estimated  that  the  TA  will  require  23  person-months  of 
consulting services, comprising at least one international and four national consultants which will 
be selected using the quality- and cost-based selection method with a quality–cost ratio of 90:10 
given the high technical complexity of the subproject. Areas of expertise required will include 
public finance, payments for ecosystem services, eco-compensation and institutional reform 
regarding the eco-compensation programs and plans, and poverty alleviation. The consultants 
will be engaged in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time) and the associated project administration instructions and/or the staff instructions.2 
 
9.  ADB’s procurement. Office equipment will be procured by shopping method under two 
contract packages.3 Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended 
from time to time) and its associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.  Analysis of the current experience of eco-compensation and other conservation programs in 
targeting rural welfare improvement and poverty alleviation prepared 
1.1 Summarize the experience and performance of a representative selection of eco-compensation and 
other conservation program case studies, with emphasis on those implemented in key ecological 
function zones (Q2 2019–Q3 2019) 
1.2 Rank and assess the importance of various program design and implementation elements on the 
effectiveness of conservation programs in the PRC to jointly achieve rural welfare improvement and 
ecological outcomes (Q3 2019–Q4 2019) 
 
2.   Policy brief integrating poverty reduction and rural welfare improvement goals with eco-
compensation developed 
2.1 Develop a poverty and high conservation value area “mapping” for the PRC, with emphasis on key 
ecological function zones, to identify regions of high overlap that would be well-suited to joint targeting 
of poverty alleviation and conservation (Q2 2019–Q4 2019) 
2.2 Review of literature summarizing international best practice in program development, design, and 
implementation for effectively achieving both conservation outcomes and rural welfare improvement 
(Q2 2019–Q3 2019) 
2.3 Organize international knowledge-sharing conference on how poverty alleviation and rural welfare 
improvement can best be linked with conservation targets (Q4 2019) 
2.4 Prepare final policy recommendations, based on the poverty mapping, summary of international best 
practice, international conference findings and the Output 1 policy brief, on next steps for integrating 
poverty alleviation with eco-compensation (Q4 2019–Q1 2020) 
 
3.  Subproject findings disseminated and shared with policymakers 
3.1 Organize workshops or meetings targeting government officials administering key ecological function 
zones to share a summary of the findings and to obtain feedback on these and current challenges 
faced by these officials in managing these zones (Q1 2020–Q3 2020) 
3.2 Present findings in selected international workshop and conferences, especially those hosted by other 
developing member countries (Q1 2020–Q3 2020) 
3.3 Publish 2–5 brief news items, articles or blogs on subproject findings (Q3 2019–Q3 2020)  
3.4 Organize study tour of five key national and provincial government officials in ADB member countries 
to strengthen the knowledge and capacity to integrate poverty reduction with eco-compensation and 
other conservation programs (Q1 2020–Q3 2020) 
3.5 Strengthen the capacity of the existing regional knowledge hub to effectively function as a community 
of practice for mainstreaming poverty reduction into eco-compensation (Q1 2019–Q2 2020)
